pr_title: [testutils] Prevent deadlocks in Latch and Await

timeline.message:
[testutils] Prevent deadlocks in Latch and Await

Await: if Await.result() is called from thread A, and its method
fires callbacks on that same thread A, they may never be invoked. This
is because the CountDownLatch is sleeping the thread A. To address this
situation, ensure that the ResultErrorEmitter function always run on a
different (new) thread.

Latch: InterruptedException was being gobbled. But, this needs to be
raised to crash the thread. Otherwise, the thread can hang.

timeline.bodyText: is there any reason why you want these threads to persist? I feel like all threads should be stopped if the test suite that started it crashes due to a certain error that is unrelated to this thread.
timeline.author: raphkim

replies.bodyText:
(Update) Oh yea I did want setDaemon(true):

setDaemon() Marks this thread as either a daemon thread or a user thread. The Java Virtual Machine exits when the only threads running are all daemon threads.

My goal was to not hang the VM.
replies.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: ah okay. that sounds like a good reason.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText: would anything ever get thrown directly to this thread?
timeline.author: raphkim

replies.bodyText:
Not if it is working properly. Before, if something was broken, it would throw on the calling thread, here. But since I've moved the call onto a new thread, I don't want the exception to just kill the thread, while the caller is still alive waiting for a response. I want it to kill the calling thread, too.
But yea - this is a safeguard. Software that is functioning as we intent it do would not trigger this condition. (But, this is after-all a testutils component, so we can't expect things passed into this method will always be functioning correctly (they may throw instead of calling error consumer, accidentally.))
replies.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: I guess it's always better safe than sorry. I just couldn't think of a scenario where anything would ever be thrown directly here now that you created a new well-contained thread.
replies.author: raphkim
